author: HM Treasury (UK Government)

resources.description: List of Public Bodies in the COINS Database (wiki/html)
List of Public Bodies in the COINS Database

organization.description:
### Expenditure Data 

There are now several detailed datasets on Government expenditure available for the UK. The most significant are Council £500 spending, the Departmental £25k spending and the Combined Online Information System (COINS).

COINS is the primary database used by HMT for recording and analysing spending. It has a pseudo-double-entry structure and is the book of "prime entry" for the budget (planning spending) and forecasted outturn (what was actually spent).

A large sample of the COINS data is publicly available at data.gov.uk. We have gathered a variety of useful information to help interpret the COINS data:

 - [Package for COINS data itself including status of current access requests](http://www.ckan.net/package/coins-data)
 - [COINS schema and field definitions](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-coins-field-definitions)

The reason that COINS is important to this project is because it contains the main high level reports on public spending and almost all other government reports on spending are directly derived from it including:

 - [Public Expenditure Statistical Analysis](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finances-pesa)
 - [Country Regional Analysis](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finances-cra)
 - [The Budget](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finance-budget)
 - [The Supplementary Budget Information](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finance-sbi)
 - [The Supply Estimates](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finance-main-supply-estimates)
 - Some of the [Office of National Statistics Blue Book](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finance-blue-book)
 - Some of the [Office of National Statistics Pink Book](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finance-pink-book)
 - [The Whole of Government Accounts](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finance-whole-of-government-accounts)

While COINS shows spending and income, we also have another dataset called the Country Regional Analysis (CRA) which shows where public spending has effect: package:ukgov-finance-cra.

### Income Data

The main package is:

 - [National income data from HMRC](http://www.ckan.net/package/hmrc-national-statistics-income-tax-and-personal-incomes)

### Additional Data

Although this isn't key data at the present it is also useful:

 - [Monthly DataBank reports of public spending](http://www.ckan.net/package/ukgov-finance-databank)   
 
[1] More details about the project -- which aims to visualise how the UK government spend public funds -- can be found at 
[Where Does My Money Go?](http://www.wheredoesmymoneygo.org/).
organization.title: Where Does My Money Go?
organization.name: wdmmg

name: coins-data
notes:
The UK Government's HM Treasury use a budgeting system called COINS. Available from 2010-06-4 at <http://data.gov.uk/dataset/coins>

### The Data COINS stores

The COINS database contains the main high level reports on public spending, including:

 - [Public Expenditure Statistical Analysis](/dataset/ukgov-finances-pesa)
 - [Country Regional Analysis](/dataset/ukgov-finance-cra)
 - [The Budget](/dataset/ukgov-finance-budget)
 - [The Supplementary Budget Information](/dataset/ukgov-finance-sbi)
 - [The Supply Estimates](/dataset/ukgov-finance-main-supply-estimates)
 - Some of the [Office of National Statistics Blue Book](/dataset/ukgov-finance-blue-book)
 - Some of the [Office of National Statistics Pink Book](/dataset/ukgov-finance-pink-book)
 - [The Whole of Government Accounts](/dataset/ukgov-finance-whole-of-government-accounts)

For an overview see this [blog post by Lisa Evans](http://blog.okfn.org/2010/05/26/in-the-beginning-there-were-mystery-boxes/).

### Public Access and Data requests

The COINS database is currently publicly available but before this was the case, several people made Freedom of Information requests to obtain it.

For example, BBC journalist Martin Rosenbaum [made a Freedom of Information Request](http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/opensecrets/2009/09/how_big_is_the_coins_database.html) for the data in September 2009.

His request was rejected. In his [BBC article](http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/opensecrets/2010/03/coins_request_rejected_by_treasury.html), he links to the [appeal rejection letter](http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/opensecrets/Coins.pdf)(PDF) from HM Treasury.

Another [request for the COINS data](http://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/copy_of_the_coins_database#incoming-76711) was made by the software engineer Julian Todd.

The details we, the Open Knowledge Foundation, obtained about the COINS database are: 

 - [The COINS data fields](/dataset/ukgov-coins-field-definitions)
 - [The COINS training materials](http://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/training_materials_for_coins#comment-9838)
 - [The contract for COINS](http://www.archive.org/details/CoinsContractPart1) including [the intellectual property rights](http://www.objectgroup.org/coins-contract-41.JPG) 

Some more details about COINS:

  * All accounts on COINS receive a PESA Transfer tag, which indicates the broad economic category of the spending if it leaves the public sector. (point 1 of http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/cra_guidance_annexc.pdf)
title: COINS data
